history.content:
Assuming you've taken 16A, this is definitely possible. Obviously, 105 is a tough course in general (so be prepared for that), but this is definitely not the worst instance of skipping a pre-req, considering that most of 16B has nothing to do with 105 (and that all of the relevant material comes in the first part of 16B anyway). Best of luck!

=========================

105's modules can roughly be divided into 1) nonideal op-amps, 2) basic device physics, and 3) transistors and their applications (with a focus on the MOSFET, mostly as amplifiers). You would need to be comfortable with phasor analysis, transfer functions (poles, zeroes, etc), and Bode plots, all of which the course assumes right from the get-go. These are all taught in the first part of 16B, but by the time 16B will have gotten to these topics, 105 will have zoomed far past. Furthermore, concepts from 16B's last module (LTI systems and the DFT) are very relevant to analog circuit design. If you have watched 16B's webcast this semester and feel extraordinarily comfortable with the material, then you might be fine, but I would still strongly recommend taking 16B beforehand.

Assuming you've taken 16A, this is definitely possible. Obviously, 105 is a tough course in general (so be prepared for that), but this is definitely not the worst instance of skipping a pre-req, considering that most of 16B has nothing to do with 105 (and that all of the relevant material comes in the first part of 16B anyway). Best of luck!

children.subject: That's so helpful for me, Thanks a lot for you advice!

history.content:
hi, I am wondering if it is possible to take EE16B and EE105 concurrently in one semester.

I also double in Physics so I had already taken the physics lower div courses.

I am just wonder if I would be able to catch up everything if I just watched this semester's EE16B webcast.
history.subject: EE16B and EE105 concurrently
